titlePart.title: The Charlatan: A Comic Opera in Three Acts

titlePage.docAuthor:
Words by Charles Klein
Music by John Philip Sousa

div.note: Transcriber's Note: This version has been transcribed from the copy in the British Library's Lord Chamberlain's Archives. The copy was submitted to the Lord Chamberlain's Office in London by the DeWolf Hopper Opera Company on December 28, 1899 for production at The Comedy Theatre.
div.head: Act 1
div.stage: Scene: Act 1 opens in Bokhara, a village in the Caucasian Mountains, under Russian rule. As the curtain rises a fair is in progress.

Discovered: Russians - Persians - Marionettes show L. Small theatre R. The CHORUS have gathered around the marionette show and are applauding same, much to the disgust of KOREFF. After applause, chorus interspersed with hand clapping, hurrahs, etc.
The following dialogue, either to music or through the music which accompanies the marionette show. At cue enter JELIKOFF at back of small theatre. He rushes down.

lg.l: Mountebanks, come waken from your dreaming
Golden dawn is breaking in the sky
Push and hustle
Noise and bustle
Is in keeping with the day
Palpitating hearts with hopes are teeming
For your posters one and all imply
You have new acts
And a few acts
Worth a fortune in their way
So beat the drum
Sound the horn
And let your barkers rend the air.
In crowds we come
On this morn
To see the country fair
Slim acrobats we adore,
But bearded ladies are a bore
The female with the iron jaw
We've seen enough of her
The pig that knows the alphabet
And plays backgammon and roulette,
And grinds "The day when you'll forget"
We want to see again.

sp.speaker: SKOBELOFF

lg.l: For your special information
I advance this declaration
My dramatic aggregation
Is a peach.
I have plays grotesque and funny
Some are English - therefore punny
So step up and pay your money
I beseech

sp.p: My first will be the beautifully sentimental, though slightly problematic play, entitled "Alphonso, the Brave, and the fair Imogene."

sp.speaker: CHORUS
sp.p: We object.

sp.speaker: SKOBELOFF
sp.p: How will the strange adventures of Jack and the Bean -

sp.speaker: CHORUS
sp.p: We object.

sp.speaker: SKOBELOFF
sp.p: Cymbeline.

sp.speaker: CHORUS
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: SKOBELOFF
sp.p: Alladrene.

sp.speaker: CHORUS
sp.p: No.

div.stage: Enter BORIS as if trying to get away from someone.

lg.l: Something watery and wavy,
A panorama of the navy
A play that deals with scenes most martial
To soldiers buttons maids are partial.
Prince Boris shall select the play
His choice and wish we'll all obey.
We'll have the story of the faithless
Knight and the philosophic maid,
She was a maid of sweet simplicitee.

sp.speaker: BORIS
sp.l: He was a knight of ancient familee.

lg.l: He swore his heart was hers forever
And that he'd never
Their love ties sever
Her joy would be his one endeavour
But lack-a-day he left her all forlorn
And then she sighed
And softly cried
"Why was I born."
Love dies when wintry skies are gray
And dead and dying are the flowers
Love sighs, and if he's wise, He'll say,
The winter's gone, I'll wait for summer showers.

sp.speaker: BORIS
sp.l: The jilted maiden dries her weeping eyes

sp.speaker: BORIS
sp.l: A fool is she who for a false love sighs

lg.l: There came another gallant wooing
And softly cooing
And likewise suing
Her wedding ring she's fondly viewing
Which proves it's good to have philosophy,
If she had moped
Or misanthroped
She'd single be,
Love dies when wintry skies, etc.
The philosophic play is told
And as the subject's rather old
We all are ready to behold
Your dancers brought from France,
You call them marvel of the age
The wonders of the present stage
lg.note: Transcriber's NOTE: "present" has been crossed out - handwritten "modern"
lg.l: The present continental rage
So let us see them dance.
Suzette,
Googoo,
Clarette,
Yeauxbleux, zou, zou.

div.stage: Dance of the Marionettes and dialogue of Koreff etc.

sp.speaker: JELIKOFF
sp.p: Good Koreff, where is our audience?

sp.speaker: KOREFF
sp.p: Over there.

sp.speaker: JELIKOFF
sp.p: They do not appear to want us.

sp.speaker: KOREFF
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: JELIKOFF
sp.p: Our art appears only to the select few.

sp.speaker: KOREFF
sp.p: Yes - very select and very few.

sp.speaker: CHORUS
sp.p: Hurrah, Hurrah!

sp.speaker: JELIKOFF
sp.p: Shade of Thespis -- list to that.

sp.speaker: KOREFF
sp.p: Such applause ne'er greeted your efforts.

sp.speaker: JELIKOFF
sp.p: Think you I cater to yon noisy rabble -- We can play without an audience. --

sp.speaker: KOREFF
sp.p: We generally do --
sp.stage: Chorus applaud marionettes and give them money. Jelikoff and Koreff watch chorus gloomily

sp.speaker: KOREFF
sp.p: I have an idea -- watch me -- do as I do -- and we'll make money fast enough.
sp.stage: Takes off part of wardrobe. Jelikoff does the same. Koreff commences to dance and Jelikoff tries to imitate him. Queer imitations of acrobatic tricks to circus music. Chorus gradually attracted towards acting booth - move over gradually and begin to applaud dancers. Koreff stops dancing and goes round with hate -- collects money -- finally Jelikoff falls exhausted on ground as Koreff is counting money.
sp.p: 'Twas my idea -- it's my money --
sp.stage: Puts money in pockets - picks up wardrobe.
sp.p: Bye Bye, Jelikoff.
sp.stage: Laughs at Jelikoff and exist L. triumphantly

sp.speaker: JELIKOFF
sp.p: Serves me right for deserting the Muse
sp.note: Transcriber's Note: Possible placement of Music No. 1d, which is not included in the script.
sp.stage: Chorus sings final stanza of opening chorus, dance, etc. etc. At end of number chorus walk about looking at sights etc.
Enter PRINCE BORIS followed by GOGOL and SOPHIA.

sp.speaker: BORIS
sp.p: Uncle Gogol, am I never to be free from this spying system?

sp.speaker: SOPHIA
sp.p: We followed you for your own sake, Count Boris.

sp.speaker: GOGOL
sp.p: You were in dangerous company nephew.

sp.speaker: BORIS
sp.p: These mountain maids dangerous?

sp.speaker: SOPHIA
sp.p: Why not, some of them are quite pretty --

sp.speaker: GOGOL
sp.p: And we love you too well to allow you to forfeit your title and estate by marrying beneath you -- eh Sophia?

sp.speaker: BORIS
sp.p: Can't I speak to a pretty woman without proposing to her. Ah -- Bows to lady, speaks to her up stage

sp.speaker: GOGOL
sp.p: The young fool is just obstinate enough to marry one of these nameless nobodies out of spite. I wish he would.

sp.speaker: SOPHIA
sp.p: You forget how much I love him.

sp.speaker: GOGOL
sp.p: And you forget his valuable inheritance which by edict of the Czar, I, his uncle and nearest of kin, inherit if he marries anyone beneath the rank of Princess. His father married a peasant girl and the Czar is bent on keeping up the lineage. Ha - ha, it's a splendid edict. He must marry a Princess, and what Princess would ever think of visiting these mountains and he can't travel without the Czar's premission - Ha, Ha.

sp.speaker: SOPHIA
sp.p: Sweetly Are you walking this way dear Boris? Points L

sp.speaker: BORIS
sp.p: No --
I understand this man is going to ply his trade here and I wish to see him.
sp.stage: Sophia takes paper out of Boris' hand goes to read it, Gogol takes it from her

sp.speaker: GOGOL
sp.p: Reads The only Demidoff - the great Demidoff, the Great and only Demidoff -- dealer in Black art - magic - and philters of sorts, sizes, shapes and sexes. Futures foretold without horoscopes, microscopes or telescopes. Crushes paper Bah, a Charlatan.

sp.speaker: BORIS
sp.p: He may furnish some amusement.

sp.speaker: GOGOL
sp.p: Is not this the fellow who just escaped being knouted for turning the Grand Duke's diamond ring into glass and was bastinaded for making a pudding in the turban of the Ameer of Afghanistan.

sp.speaker: BORIS
sp.p: The same
A pudding in the Royal Turban - ha ha - I'm curious to see the fellow --

lg.l: As the agent in advance of Demidoff the grand
Magician to the Czar
The only living star
Who keeps a private car
And band
I have the honour to announce he will be here to-day.
He ranks pre-eminent
Which is very evident
To almost any gent
We say
I hear his foot-fall's music coming near
Hurrah for Demidoff!
The man of mystery will now appear
Hurrah for Demidoff!
Get your purses ready all
Same pride for short as tall
I hear my master call
Great Demidoff is here!

div.note: Transcriber's Note: The script indicates that Music No. 2b "Pluto's Partner" was replaced with "Have you got that tired feeling?" after the opening on Broadway and publication of the score by the John Church Company. It was published under a separate cover, and is digitized on the Library of Congress website. What is indicated in the script is only the first verse, even though there is both a second verse and chorus which were used in the show.

lg.l: Have you got that tired feeling
Does your heart go pit-a-pat
Do you feel your senses reeling
Till you don't know what you're at
When the breakfast bell is ringing
Do you wish to stay in bed
When you hear the birdies singing
Do you wish that you were dead
Do you read the Marriage Column
In a vacant sort of way
And say in accents solemn
Well at last she's caught that jay
Do you crave for cream and pickles
Though they always disagree
I'll bet a hundred nickles
You are yearning for a he

div.stage: Enter KATRINKA, DRESSED AS A BOY -- she throws coloured circulars among the chorus, who eagerly grab for them.
Enter DEMIDOFF, drawing after him a four wheel caravan to which he is harnessed, caravan is placed C., between small theatre and marionette show.

During this song Katrinka blows Musette in wrong place till the end of the song, then Demidoff is so annoyed at being interrupted that he takes Musette. Musette made like a telescope, Demidoff takes it and flattens down, hands it back to her

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: Good people. The hitherto hidden pages of the future are now open to public inspection. With the assistance of Methusaleh's grandmother who is seated in yon caravan I can read the stars in seven different languages including Sanskritt, Aulic, Plat Deautsch, Spanish and other dead languages. I can cast horoscopes without a mould, make your fortune while you wait, and read your thoughts even before you yourselves can think the thought that you are thinking.

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: Such minor gifts as second sight, sleight of hand, conjuring and prestidigitation, I regard as only the a, b, c, of my profession -- per example: I take your watch. Takes watch from Chorus man L., shows same to audience, closes it up in his hand, blows on hand I don't even say - Tempus - fugit -- Slips watch into pocket Dear me how time flies.

sp.speaker: PEASANT
sp.p: My watch. Give it me back.

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: I gave it to you back - Bus. turn man round - watch is hanging on back of his coat. Omnes laugh A mere nothing -- a mere nothing -- that is only looking backward. Points to peasant's back What we would peer into is the future.

sp.speaker: PEASANT
sp.p: Can you tell fortunes by hand?

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: Angry at interruption Certainly, all fortunes told by hand - I haven't a machine made fortune on the premises. Takes hand Your life-line is somewhat obscure - the addition of a little soap and water will make it much clearer. Ten kopecks please. Peasant withdraws hand hastily. Now -- to bridge that awful gulf 'twixt us and futurity -- Katrinket notify the seeress.

sp.speaker: KATRINKA
sp.p: Oh, what's the use?

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: forgetting his grandiloquence You notify that seeress!

sp.speaker: KATRINKA
sp.p: No, I won't!

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: Katrinka leave my presence.

sp.speaker: KATRINKA
sp.p: What presents did you ever give me?

sp.speaker: SOPHIA
sp.p: Holding out her hand. Aside to Demidoff Tell me - am I destined to remain single all my life?

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: Looks at Sophia I'm afraid you stand a royal chance -- Reads hand If your face was your fortune you'd be permanently broke. Looks closely at hand Here are marriage lines.

sp.speaker: SOPHIA
sp.p: Joyfully Ah ---

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: Yes - but dear me - how unfortunate - they are your parents -

sp.speaker: BORIS
sp.p: I'll ask the knave a question. Sophia hands Demidoff money

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: Thanks - I'll give you change presently.

sp.speaker: BORIS
sp.p: Look you, fellow - can you tell me - by the stars - by incantation - or by deviltry of any sort - Am I to wed - what is my bride's station in life -- is she --

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: One question at a time please. Prepare to gaze on the mighty Prophetess of Caucasia, the seeress of Tophet. Oh, mighty seeress -- what is the matrimonial future of this young gentleman. Hush -- With awe Let no one breathe -- we are on the brink of the future.

sp.speaker: KATRINKA
sp.p: Look out you don't fall in.

sp.speaker: ANNA
sp.p: Bus. starts He will marry.

sp.speaker: BORIS
sp.p: Aside By St. Nicholas, a sweet voice for such a hag --

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: What will be her station in life?

sp.speaker: ANNA
sp.p: She will be -- hesitates

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: Well - that's easy - she will be his wife - won't she?

sp.speaker: ANNA
sp.p: Yes - Yes --

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: Aside to Anna What's the matter with you?

sp.speaker: BORIS
sp.p: Her name? Her name?

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: The gentleman will please not crowd the seeress. The books of the future are not always written legibly -- The name might be blotted, you can't tell. Come speak!

sp.speaker: ANNA
sp.p: Bus. I cannot --- I --- Bus. broke up

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: Seeing that Anna is affected The book of the future is closed for the present. Draws curtain of caravan

sp.speaker: BORIS
sp.p: Stop -- another question --

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p:
Too late -- Chorus laugh at failure of trick. Open curtains. Anna is not visible
Possible placement of Music No. 3. Not included in script version.
After music no. Chorus, Gogol, Boris and Sophia exit

sp.speaker: KATRINKA
sp.p: To Jelikoff Do you know you are taking the bread and butter out of my mouth-

sp.speaker: JELIKOFF
sp.p: Am I -- where is it -- I'm starving.

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: As Anna leaves caravan Here come back -- do you want to be seen?

sp.speaker: ANNA
sp.p: No, but I - I - I want to leave this wretched life --

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: By what route -- poison, cold steel or water? By St. Nicholas you're an ambitious lot. Look at that black and blue pair over there -- points to Jelikoff and you, instead of reading the future forget even the past and present --

sp.speaker: ANNA
sp.p: I could not deceive the young man. Aside

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p:
Deceive him, nonsense -- he wouldn't believe you if you did deceive him.
Transcriber's Note: Another possible placement of Music No. 3., as suggested by William Martin and Jerrold Fisher.

sp.speaker: ANNA
sp.p: Have you had breakfast, Jelikoff?

sp.speaker: JELIKOFF
sp.p: No -- Brightening up

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: Then you can clear away.

sp.speaker: KATRINKA
sp.p: How do you like your new job? Anna laughs

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: Stop laughing -- matters are serious -- if I don't make a strike soon I'll have to shut up shop. Anna you must make a rich marriage.

sp.speaker: ANNA
sp.p: Rich marriage -- ha ha -- who would marry the seeress of Tophet --

sp.speaker: GOGOL
sp.p: Coming forward I know a someone who would --

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: The Deputy Governor! Assuming his mysterious air Would your Excellency like to peer into the future?

sp.speaker: GOGOL
sp.p: Looking at Anna Rather a young seeress.

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: You've got it upside down. Bus.

sp.speaker: GOGOL
sp.p: Bus with paper Your prospectus says something about showing a young man the woman he is going to marry -

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: My famous cabinet trick nothing easier.

sp.speaker: GOGOL
sp.p: For a consideration I want you to produce in your cabin a Princess --

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: Make it a Queen and I'll produce four

sp.speaker: GOGOL
sp.p: You will perform your trick and exhibit this girl as a counterfeit of the Princess Stephanie of, of....Rushkofski --

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: Of what Kofski?

sp.speaker: GOGOL
sp.p: Rushkofski.

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: Which kofski is that?

sp.speaker: GOGOL
sp.p: The Princess is dead and the title is extinct. I'll see that the girl is suitably attired. Boris will see her. She will afterwards appear as the real princess, and he will recognize her as the figure he saw in your Cabinet -- he may fall in love with her -- he may marry her.

sp.speaker: ANNA
sp.p: Bobbing out of cabinet Glorious -- Glorious -- this is like a fairy tale.

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: Yes, it's too much like a fairy tale -- how about his social position? Does he belong to my set?

sp.speaker: GOGOL
sp.p: He is my nephew.

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: That's not a bad start. But why - doesn't he select his own bride?

sp.speaker: GOGOL
sp.p: Aside to Demidoff He's bashful. I want him to get married - he thinks he must marry a Princess - a mental delusion of course - Bus. Points to caravan She will consent?

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: She is with me. Father-in-law to a rich Prince. We shall be uncles. Slaps him on the back

sp.speaker: GOGOL
sp.p: Resents this I will send the necessary dresses at once and spread a report that the Princess is coming and fetch Prince Boris.

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: Boris -- Borry - borrow -- there's a ring about that name that plays a delicious tattoo on the drum of my ear. Anna -- Anna you heard - our fortunes are made.

sp.speaker: ANNA
sp.p: Shakes her head I don't like this marriage business - It's too sudden and I --

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: What have you got to do with it? Anna, it would be a source of great joy to me if you'd mind your own business - why you were pleased at first.

sp.speaker: ANNA
sp.p: I've changed my mind.

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: I'm glad of it -- the one you had was perfectly useless to you.

sp.speaker: ANNA
sp.p: I see - you're tired of me - you want to be rid of me

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: Do you think I would desert you just because you made a rich marriage - You do me a gross injustice.

sp.speaker: ANNA
sp.p: But father marriage is a serious matter when you come to think of it.

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: Then don't think of it. Look on the whole thing as a joke got up for the benefit of posterity -- Good gracious me, your mother married -- you can't do much worse than she did!

sp.speaker: ANNA
sp.p: Looks at Demidoff No! I can't.

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: And if you do as badly as she did, you'll do very well - Anna laughs I wish you'd stop that meaningless titter, our wealth and happiness are at stake.

sp.speaker: ANNA
sp.p: Supposing he won't have me.

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: Suppose nothing -- The Deputy Governor is rich and will pay us well anyhow. You're always borrowing trouble.

sp.speaker: ANNA
sp.p: But --

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: But what? With the exception of your sainted mother you are the most uncomfortable girl I ever met.

sp.speaker: ANNA
sp.p: Father -- At caravan

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: Pettishly Why I was born to be a father -- why was -- will you stop picking holesin that curtain? Enter JELIKOFF and KATRINKA L. Jelikoff is eating an apple. Demidoff takes it away and eats it himself. Ah, just in time -- I have work for you both.

sp.speaker: JELIKOFF
sp.p: Have you any dinner for us?

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: How dare you talk of dinner at such a time as this -- I am about to perform a gigantic optical illusion. Listen -- Anna is to be the Princess Rushkofaki -- you, Katrinka, will be her page in waiting and you, Jelikoff, what can you be? Suddenly By the Great White Czar, we have no lady in waiting -- You, Jelikoff, must doff the buskin for the bustle.

sp.speaker: JELIKOFF
sp.p: Aye - I once did enact the Queen mother in an affair written by an alleged English poet - t'was called Hamlet - a stupid play but --

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: Will the ghost walker in it. Didn't it? Will is won't in this unless you are careful.

sp.speaker: KATRINKA
sp.p: Why not let me be the lady in waiting?

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: You?

sp.speaker: KATRINKA
sp.p: Yes - I - folks say I somewhat resemble a girl.

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: Surveying her Then folks must be blind.

sp.speaker: KATRINKA
sp.p: Angrily stamping her foot It's you who are blind.

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: Boy you are speaking to Demidoff -- the all-wise analyst of human character.

sp.speaker: KATRINKA
sp.p:
True - I forgot - Aside The dear old bluff
Enter TWO SERVANTS with large basket

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p:
What is that?
SERVANT From his Excellency the Deputy Governor.

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p:
Aside He's kept his word, the Princess's wardrobe -- Put it in there, get into your new togs, we're going into Society. Points to caravan, they place basket behind same and exit
Enter BORIS and GOGOL

sp.speaker: BORIS
sp.p: It's a clever trick if he can do it.

sp.speaker: GOGOL
sp.p: The knave says he can.

sp.speaker: BORIS
sp.p: Where is he - disappeared eh? Let's interview the seeress in his absence. Tries to pull curtain of caravan but Gogol prevents him.

sp.speaker: GOGOL
sp.p: No, no Boris --

sp.speaker: BORIS
sp.p:
If this Demidoff is going to show me my future bride I want to make sure there's no deception.
Enter SOPHIA L., hastily.

sp.speaker: SOPHIA
sp.p: Father, Boris -- have you heard the news?

sp.speaker: BORIS
sp.p: What news?

sp.speaker: SOPHIA
sp.p: There is a report among the villagers that the Princess Stephanie of Ruchkofski is here, or on her way here, -- is it true, have you seen her -- why does she come here --

sp.speaker: BORIS
sp.p: A Princess, eh? --- I wonder if she is young and beautiful.

sp.speaker: SOPHIA
sp.p: No, there's not a Princess in the Court of Russia who can claim to be even passably good looking.

sp.speaker: GOGOL
sp.p: She is evidently not here yet.

sp.speaker: BORIS
sp.p: Perhaps it's only village gossip. I'm going to take a look at that seeress if I -- Pulls curtain aside. Demidoff discovered smoking. sold -- by St. Nicholas.

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: No, sold by Demidoff, though I should call it more of a give away. To what am I indebted for the honour of this visit. Oh, yes I promised to do my great trick. To Gogol You want to see your bride that is to be.

sp.speaker: GOGOL
sp.p: I - no thanks -- I've had my cake and eaten it - this young gentleman -

sp.speaker: BORIS
sp.p: Laughs Yes -- I -- of course it's a joke.

sp.speaker: SOPHIA
sp.p: Aside to Dem. One thousand rubles if you show him my likeness.

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: Cash?

sp.speaker: SOPHIA
sp.p: No -- but I --

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: Madam, I do not sell my art -- Aside I may sell my patrons, but not my art. Aside - To the caravan as Sophia goes disconsolately over to Gogol and Boris. Are you ready Anna? Then hurry up -- I must gain time. Aloud Now, sire, examine the caravan -- you will see that there is nothing inside but a few domestic data, and nothing outside but ourselves. There can be no possible way for a living being to enter without my knowledge -- no fire-escapes to climb up, no side doors to avoid municipal authority, or to quote an eminent literateur - there ain't no nuthin' --

sp.speaker: BORIS
sp.p: Is it visible to the naked eye?

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: To the naked -- such a decollete expression - to the unclothed eye, yes.

sp.speaker: ANNA
sp.p: Back stage Go ahead.

sp.speaker: BORIS
sp.p: What was that?

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: Observe my ventriloquial powers -- Are you there Anna?

sp.speaker: ANNA
sp.p: Yes ---

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: Are you sure?

sp.speaker: ANNA
sp.p: Of course I am.

sp.speaker: BORIS
sp.p: Wonderful!

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: That's the way I deceived the Marajah of Punjaub -- great boy the Marajah - he was so impressed with my ventriloquial powers that he - that he conferred on me the order of the double epiglottis. I feel the propitious moment has arrived -- that we are on the brink of the unforseen, unfathomable future.

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: Caballa - Abdalla - Hawoka - Sulon.

sp.speaker: CHORUS
sp.p: Hawoka - Sulon.

lg.l: Venus, Goddes of love, ope wide thy shell-like ears
And by the memory of thy loves
The cooing of the snowy doves
I, Demidoff, the great Mumbo-jumbo of the seers
Direct you
Expect you
By mystic sign and magic rite
To send his heart's delight
Of future years.

sp.speaker: CHORUS
sp.p: On wings of lightning she appears.

lg.l: Love's the pleasure, love's the pain
Love's the sickle, love's the grain
Love's the sunshine, love's the rain
Love is everything.
Oh visions from the realms of light
My dream of love so fair, so sweet
Bright guiding star of summer night
without thee life is incomplete.
Love's the pleasure, love's the pain
Love's the sickle, love's the grain
Love's the sunshine, love's the rain
Love is everything.

div.stage: Calcium on caravan as curtain noiselessly opens discovering Anna in regal costume. Anna sings a few words to mystic strain. Boris takes it up - openly manifesting his admiration for Anna. He attempts to rush to her: he is prevented by Gogol and chorus. Calcium lights quickly taken off Anna and curtain drawn. Lights up Boris rushes to caravan draws aside curtain, but Anna and Demidoff have both disappeared. Chorus affrighted sing of magic. Boris expresses sorrow at the disappearance of such an angel of beauty, wonders who she is etc. etc., as chorus gradually disperse. Stage cleared leaving Boris seated at table R. looking glommily into space. Gogol at back watching him and Sophia watches obviously jealous of Boris' attitude.

sp.speaker: GOGOL
sp.p: A clever trick, eh?

sp.speaker: BORIS
sp.p: What grace! What beauty!

sp.speaker: SOPHIA
sp.p: Hah - an illusion at best, a painted face. Why it's often practised in Hindoostan, a clever sham.

sp.speaker: BORIS
sp.p: With a sigh I wish it were real.

sp.speaker: GOGOL
sp.p: Rubbing his hands triumphantly The young fool nibbles at the bait

sp.speaker: BORIS
sp.p: Musingly My bride to be - he said - Distant shouts off stage L. Gogol goes up, looks off L.

sp.speaker: GOGOL
sp.p: Aside looking at Boris Now he'll swallow it hook and all - Shouts nearer

sp.speaker: SOPHIA
sp.p: Why do they shout?

sp.speaker: GOGOL
sp.p: Looking off, describing the scene A gaily dressed party of travellers are entering from the Plecknard. They are alighting --

sp.speaker: SOPHIA
sp.p: In consternation Strangers?

sp.speaker: GOGOL
sp.p: Yes, two ladies, a page and a - courier.

sp.speaker: SOPHIA
sp.p: Goes up stage, looks off L. Father - do you see - it's the same one - I'll swear - Looks at Boris. Aside He will see her --

sp.speaker: GOGOL
sp.p: No, you're mistaken - it can't be. Boris, - do you recognise...

sp.speaker: SOPHIA
sp.p: No - no - don't ask him.

sp.speaker: BORIS
sp.p: At table not noticing I am going home. I shall petition the Czar to allow me to leave here. I --- Oh, why was I ever born?

lg.l: When the wintry moon is bright
And the curtain of the night
Is illumined by the stars that shyly twinkle
When the frost is in the air
And the snow lies everywhere
There's no music like the sleigh bells merry tinkle
Hear the horses as the neigh
They are telling in their way
That we should be off before the moon retires for the night,
Here the jingle of the bells
Faintly echo in the dells
Ye ho, ready, yo ho steady, hear us shouting with delight
On, see the horses gaily speeding
On, over roads bedecked with snow
On, now our steeds are bravely leading
Over hill and dale we madly go.
On, see the horses gaily speeding
On, over roads bedecked with snow
On, now our steeds are bravely leading
Over hill and dale we madly go.
Through the village on the hill
By the turnpike and the rill
Crackling o'er the ice that by our weight is bending
Turning for the homeward race
See the steed with carless grace
Through the snow drift in the valley softly wanding
Quick again away we speed
Each one trying for the lead
While the moon grows dim and dimmer as the shadows fill the night
Catch us if you can we cry
As like lightning we dash by
Yo ho ready, yo ho steady
Hear us shouting with delight
Oh, see the horse gaily speeding etc.

sp.speaker: CHORUS
sp.l: Oh see the horses gaily speeding etc.

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: The Princess Stephanie of Ruchofski is much moved by this friendly demonstration. Ah, do I not observe the Deputy Governor - Raseloff Gogol.

sp.speaker: GOGOL
sp.p: You do me the honour to recognize me.

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: I do. The Czar once showed me a picture of you -

sp.speaker: KATRINKA
sp.p: No, it was me he showed it to -

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: So he did, but I was there wasn't I -- Aside I'll damage that boy yet - To Anna Your Highness allow me to present Raseloff Gogol, Deputy Governor of Bokhara. Gogol bows

sp.speaker: ANNA
sp.p: Delighted Raises veil

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: Madam Jelikoff Gogol bows

sp.speaker: JELIKOFF
sp.p: Delighted Bows, nearly falls A plauge on these skirts.

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: Aside to Jelikoff Her Highness will condescend --

sp.speaker: KATRINKA
sp.p: Permit me to introduce myself. I am Ivan Ivanowschefsky, page in waiting to Her Highness Princess Stephanie of Ruchkofski - Pushes Jelikoff who nearly falls over

sp.speaker: JELIKOFF
sp.p: Tragically Boy -

sp.speaker: KATRINKA
sp.p: There now don't you begin.

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: Laughing to conceal anger I'm afraid we have spoiled him - you see we love him so. I was about to say - Her Highness and suite will utilize your establishment -

sp.speaker: GOGOL
sp.p: Surprised Live at my house -

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: Her Highness will condescend to do so Looks at Anna, Anna bows. Jelikoff bows and Katrinka bows

sp.speaker: JELIKOFF
sp.p: And by my haldom a right merry time we'll have.

sp.speaker: GOGOL
sp.p: My house is too small.

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: We'll make it larger -- friends you may feast to your heart's content till sundown. The Deputy governor will pay the score - Omnes shout

sp.speaker: GOGOL
sp.p: I -- no -- no --

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: What, you refuse, then Her Highness will pay - come -

sp.speaker: GOGOL
sp.p: Aside to Demidoff You'll ruin me!

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p:
Aside Princess come nigh Offering his hand to Princess.
Enter BORIS

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: Your Highness, the Deputy Governer anxiously awaits us.

sp.speaker: BORIS
sp.p: Carrying Paper Uncle - here is my petition to the Czar Anna lifts veil, Boris sees her.

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: My, boy the Princess jokes are rated as astounding

sp.speaker: ANNA
sp.p: No, no I am

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: A lady of the land.

div.note: Most likely, original placement of Music No. 6.

div.head: The Charlatan
ACT II
div.note: Transcriber's Note: Act II and III bear an English type writing service stamp and dramatically different formatting, suggesting these two acts were re-transcribed in London, whereas Act I bears no type writing stamp and could be a copy of the American version.
Transcriber's Note: The London script does not include Music No. 7: I am the Seventh Son.
div.stage: Scene: Interior of Russian home. Portico L. window (trellis effect) R. Entrance C.R.F. and room extending off R. Caravan L.C. concealed by curtains. Church seen off R.C., etc., practical. Chorus to use same.
ENTER JELIKOFF R. pulling open curtains. Lights up Full.

sp.speaker: JELIKOFF
sp.p: Demidoff! Awake - awake.

div.stage: Demidoff L.C. wakes up with start - looks round, suddenly looks at table, hurriedly feels in pockets - then grabs JELLIKOFF by the collar.

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: Give me that money.

sp.speaker: JELIKOFF
sp.p: R.C. What money?

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: And then I woke up. Let me dream again. Why did you wake me up you old chump?

sp.speaker: JELIKOFF
sp.p: Do you forget that Prince Boris weds Anna today?

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: Yes - yes, of course, but I - Rubs forehead furiously The loss of that hundred thousand has upset me - I had it - and it got away -

sp.speaker: JELIKOFF
sp.p: But why sleep here?

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: Anna is in that room. Points L. And I must watch her till after the ceremony. She might tell Boris the truth -- the easiest money I ever --

sp.speaker: JELIKOFF
sp.p: Demidoff - I tire of this apparel, I --

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: After the marriage you may return to your native garments.

sp.speaker: JELIKOFF
sp.p: That's all very well, but one of Gogol's friends, Captain Peshofki swears he will marry me.

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: What have I to do with your amours - tell him you're married.

sp.speaker: JELIKOFF
sp.p: I did, and he swears he will kill my husband.

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: Good.

sp.speaker: JELIKOFF
sp.p: Yes, but I told him - I told him that you - were my husband.

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p:
Gets up You bearded lady! Haven't I enough trouble with....
ENTER KATRINKA R.
Anna's marriage without bother about my own assassination! To Katrinka What do you want? I thought I had put you out.

sp.speaker: KATRINKA
sp.p: You did, but I came back - I want to talk to you.
sp.stage: Takes chair, sits down opposite Demidoff: takes out cigarettes, offer Demidoff one.
sp.p: You can get out.

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: Have you any more orders?

sp.speaker: KATRINKA
sp.p: Yes - To JELLIKOFF Shut the door after you.

sp.speaker: JELIKOFF
sp.p: As he EXITS What a rude boy. Exit R.

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: Young man, are you aware that I am in my own house?

sp.speaker: KATRINKA
sp.p: Well, it won't be yours after I've got through with you, it will be ours. Now see here Demidoff I won't beat around the bust - but will make a straightforward proposition - Unless you take me into full partnership - I'll explode this fictitious fake about a Princess and you and your pretentions and ambitions will be sent sky ward ---

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: Surveying Katrinka admiringly Have you any sisters?

sp.speaker: KATRINKA
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: If you have I'd like to marry one of them - all I need is a wife with a four ply ball-bearing triple expansion nerve like yours and in six months I'd own Russia and have an option on the rest of Europe. Get out - and get out quick ... Throws her out of chair

sp.speaker: KATRINKA
sp.p: L. Do you know, Demidoff, I rather like you, and I hate to see you make an idiot of yourself. Demidoff advance to him as if to strike him.

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: Say, I'll knock -

sp.speaker: KATRINKA
sp.p: You don't dare -

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: C. weakens, hesitates Well, what if I don't - you're too small, you're - oh!

div.stage: ENTER SOPHIA R. Demidoff Bus: bows to Sophia.

sp.speaker: SOPHIA
sp.p: R Have you asked him?

sp.speaker: KATRINKA
sp.p: L Yes - I -

sp.speaker: SOPHIA
sp.p: Demidoff you will promise - this marriage between your daughter and Prince Boris must not take place - think of me.

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: Think of you - think of me. Don't I count - My sun is past meridian and I've got to fill a stocking for my old age - a rich son-in-law is good enought for me, thank you.

sp.speaker: SOPHIA
sp.p: But Demidoff, this marriage will ruin Boris.

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: No, not quite, I'll allow him a small annuity - Cross R

sp.speaker: SOPHIA
sp.p: But -

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: R It's no use your butting, I cannot come between these two young hearts, in the meantime I must get ready for the ceremony.

sp.speaker: SOPHIA
sp.p: C Demidoff -

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p:
No - where Anna's interests are concerned I am as adamantine concretion of immovable matter.
Stalks off R with tragic dignity.

sp.speaker: KATRINKA
sp.p: L Isn't he lovely?

sp.speaker: SOPHIA
sp.p: My dear you're in love with him.

sp.speaker: KATRINKA
sp.p: Can I help it - he's such a colossal fraud.

sp.speaker: SOPHIA
sp.p: So are you - you'll make a charming pair. Boris will marry a beggar - he will lose his title and estates - suppose I warn him - no, he would not believe it - besides, father would never forgive me - Suddenly Katrinka, suppose another Princess Ruchkowski came to Bokhara, suppose you appear on the scene as the real Princess Ruchkowski - it will prevent the marriage.

sp.speaker: KATRINKA
sp.p: But -

sp.speaker: SOPHIA
sp.p: If you refuse, I tell everyone your sex, as a Princess you might attract Demidoff.

sp.speaker: KATRINKA
sp.p: You know then. Well I left home fascinated by Demidoff's magic art.

sp.speaker: SOPHIA
sp.p: I know all about it. Do you think you can deceive me as Anna and Demidoff have deceived each other.

sp.speaker: KATRINKA
sp.p:
Clasp hands Me, I see, yes. I'm to be the real Princess. I'll make Anna look like 30 Kopecks. Cross R
ENTER ANNA in full white wedding dress DL. She is sad.

sp.speaker: SOPHIA
sp.p: Aside Hush - come to my rooms, I will explain - Aloud How is your highness this morning - I trust your highness is well.

sp.speaker: ANNA
sp.p: Yes. Aside She is mocking me.

sp.speaker: SOPHIA
sp.p:
Has your Highness any orders to issue? ANNA shakes her head. Perhaps your highness wishes to be alone - ANNA nods affirmatively
To Katrinka Come.
As they go towards DR, ENTER BORIS, he bows to them in a dignified manner and goes forward to greet Anna.

sp.speaker: KATRINKA
sp.p: Aside to Sophia You're not 1-2-50 with him.

sp.speaker: SOPHIA
sp.p:
Why I'm only 32 --
SOPHIA EXIIS door R followed by KATRINKA.

sp.speaker: BORIS
sp.p: R The wedding guests will soon be here and in an hour we shall meet never to part again.

sp.speaker: ANNA
sp.p: L In an hour we may part never to meet again.

sp.speaker: BORIS
sp.p: What do you mean? Stephanie, you love me?

sp.speaker: ANNA
sp.p: Crosses to chair. Yes, but - I - I have forbodings of some impending danger. Sits in chair.

sp.speaker: BORIS
sp.p:
Love should drive such fears away.
Action at back of stage, CHORUS going into church
Music No. 8

lg.l: Before the twilight shadows change to tints of Misty grey
Before the glinting sunbeams on the waters cease to play
The bridal bells with sweetly sound the clanging roundelay
Proclaim the world that we are one
Together drifting on life's stream
The golden days of golden dream
With love that ever constant theme
Till the sands of time are run.
The lilies of your love will die; the rose will lose its bloom
The darkness of a sunless time will fill your heart with gloom,
Tho' I should seek the dreary desolation of the tomb
You are my own, my earth my sun.
Together drifting on life's stream
The golden days a golden dream
With love the ever constant theme
Till the sands of time are run.
The Orange flower blossoms in the young brides hair
Will the wine be sweet
Will we taste the meat,
When the orange flower blossoms in the young bride's hair
The wine is sweet
We taste the meat
And bless the pair.

sp.speaker: BORIS
sp.p: My Princess.

sp.speaker: ANNA
sp.p: No, no -- Oh Boris - could you forgive me if -

sp.speaker: GOGOL
sp.p: Ah, here you are Boris - I thought I would find you with the Princess Ruchkowski.

sp.speaker: ANNA
sp.p: I hate that name.

sp.speaker: GOGOL
sp.p: Well, you will soon change it for another - Come Boris, the guests were assembling in the church when I left.

sp.speaker: ANNA
sp.p: L Boris - I must speak to you before the ceremony.

sp.speaker: GOGOL
sp.p:
No, no - after - Dragging Boris towards door. After - I - I am sure your highness would not wish to keep everyone waiting -
Organ or choral effect off stage. Omnes listen. The preliminary services have begun.
ENTER JELIKOFF R, dressed as a bridesmaid.

sp.speaker: JELIKOFF
sp.p: C Come your highness your bridesmaids await us. To Boris And your two dozen best men are as impatient as if it were their wedding.

sp.speaker: GOGOL
sp.p:
R Go Boris -
Boris throws a kiss to Anna and rushes off R.
Gleefully Victory - victory - at last - To Jelifkoff Madame where is Demidoff?

sp.speaker: JELIKOFF
sp.p: I was helping him to dress when a messenger came and he kicked me out -

sp.speaker: GOGOL
sp.p: Kicked you out?

sp.speaker: JELIKOFF
sp.p:
Yes. BUS But I was too well protected for him to do much damage -
ENTER DEMIDOFF quickly, he is breathless.

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: The game is up!

sp.speaker: GOGOL
sp.p: R Up!

sp.speaker: ANNA
sp.p: C Up!!

sp.speaker: JELIKOFF
sp.p: LC UP!!!

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: RC One echo at a time please - yes - To GOGOL You've muddled up the whole business.

sp.speaker: GOGOL
sp.p: Muddled -

sp.speaker: JELIKOFF
sp.p: Mud.

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: Yes - that will probably be our nom de plums in the future -

sp.speaker: GOGOL
sp.p: Be more explicit.

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: I will - Do you know you have out-balanced Ballam's most asinine ass - do you know that the seven foolish virgins are wise old women compared to you - Do you know that - but what's the use of multiplying similes - it can all be conveyed in the expressive through inelegant term - chump

sp.speaker: GOGOL
sp.p: What has happened?

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: Oh nothing - a mere trifle - the real Princess Stephanie of Ruchkowski has turned up - that's all - Oh we're not in the puree, oh dear no.

sp.speaker: GOGOL
sp.p: But there is no Princess Stephanie living.

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: Well, up to date there are two of them. A courier has just informed she arrived last night - incognite - she has heard of this marriage and demands and explanation.

sp.speaker: ANNA
sp.p:
Crosses to D. Father, I am glad this has happened - I always hated deception.
Taken off orange blossoms and wreaths

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p:
Child - you are stabbing your fond and devoted parent in the back - don't add to my vale of tears - this marriage must take place now, its our only chance. Whatever happens Prince Boris will protect papa.
BUS: fixes wreath all wrong

sp.speaker: ANNA
sp.p: It is cruel - cruel.

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: Cruel - you love him - he loves you.

sp.speaker: ANNA
sp.p: Yes - but -

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p:
Marriages are made in Heaven, a most respectable factory, and that relieves you of all responsibility.
ENTER PAGE R
PAGE Your Excellency - the services have begun.

sp.speaker: GOGOL
sp.p:
We come at once -
Waives page away. He EXITS.

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: How dare they ring up the curtain without me - tell them to start over again. To GOGOL What about this extra layer of Princess?

sp.speaker: GOGOL
sp.p: The Czar must have conferred the title on someone. I never thought of that.

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p:
I wish the Czar would mind his own business instead of mixing in our affairs - To JELIKOFF Take Anna to the church - we'll follow.
JELIKOFF takes ANNA's arm, half drags her to DR

sp.speaker: ANNA
sp.p: Father - one last appeal.

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p:
My word is given to Gogol - if he will release me I will release you - Gogol - spare my child.
GOGOL BUS: waves his hand.
Must I ply - plea in vain - have a father's tears no weight with you?
GOGOL shakes his head and goes up to ANNA.
You see he has a heart of stone, and a head of wood.

sp.speaker: JELIKOFF
sp.p:
Come little one - it will soon be over - it's only just like having a tooth pulled -
EXIT ANNA and JELIKOFF R

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: After the wedding we'll see the Princess - you can tell her it was a joke - say we did it to win a bet.

sp.speaker: GOGOL
sp.p: No, you tell her.

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: Why me -- Who am I that I should be selected for such a delicate macheveliian mission?

sp.speaker: GOGOL
sp.p: You are more diplomatic - more insinuating than me.

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p:
Perhaps you are right - I might make an impression on her, a deep impression, who can tell - why should not I aspire to a Princess? Come -
Goes toward door
You have provided a wedding dinner for our guests.

sp.speaker: GOGOL
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p:
No bargain counter - Dairy kitchen lunch, we must have the best the market affords - there's not a mean bone in my body.
They are about to EXIT door R. arm in arm when ENTER SOPHIA hastily.

sp.speaker: SOPHIA
sp.p: Father - Princess Stephanie of Ruchkowski is here, direct from Moscow. She demands an instant audience with the Princess's courier.

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: What does she want to see me for?

sp.speaker: SOPHIA
sp.p: Boris' marriage must be delayed -

sp.speaker: GOGOL
sp.p:
To Sophia Yes, I'll delay it - To Demidoff Not if I know it - keep the Princess here until the ceremony's over.
ENTER PAGE R
PAGE Her Imperial Highness, the Princess Stephanie of Ruchkowski.
ENTER KATRINKA dressed magnificently as the Princess same dress as ANNA Act 1. GOGOL is about to EXIT L.

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: No - no, don't leave me here alone - I - SOPHIA is following GOGOL off L. Sophia - EXIT SOPHIA laughing at DEMIDOFF.

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: Not daring to look at her. Your highness - I - we - Looks at DL The - Did you -- or - it's - a - it's a fine day, isn't it?

sp.speaker: KATRINKA
sp.p: Sternly I am not here to discuss the weather.

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: L No - there are plenty of other things we can talk about - er - if we can only think of them. It is a fine day though - isn't it - Laughs The weather will keep bobbing up.

sp.speaker: KATRINKA
sp.p: R I understand the Princess Ruchkowski -

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: Ah, don't let us talk about ourselves - it smacks so of egotism - Looks at her, starts. ----- who is it you remind me of?

sp.speaker: KATRINKA
sp.p: Sir!

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: Pause Did you speak?

sp.speaker: KATRINKA
sp.p: No, but I will. You are fictitious courier - to a still more fictitious Princess. Seats herself.

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: It was a joke - upon my word of honour as a gentleman - it was a joke. Aside I've met that face before, but where - where...

sp.speaker: KATRINKA
sp.p: A joke the Czar will punish most severly -

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: It's Gogol's joke not mine - he's the Deputy Governor. He commanded and I obeyed.

sp.speaker: KATRINKA
sp.p: I should never have discovered it had I not be hunting for my brother Katrinket, who ran off with a travelling magician Demidoff.

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: Katrinket? Dear little Katrinket your brother. Princess I thought there was an air of familiarity - behold in me your brother's dearest friend and bosom companion.

sp.speaker: KATRINKA
sp.p: Friend?

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: Friend - benefactor - father -aye almost mother - Why Damon and Pythias were mortal enemies compared to us.

sp.speaker: KATRINKA
sp.p: You love him?

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: I would cut off my left ear to please him. Ah, Princess, for his sake you will forgive Gogol's ill-timed humour.

sp.speaker: KATRINKA
sp.p: Yes, I may forgive Gogol, but I intend to have Demidoff flung into prison Cross to L.

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: Frightened What for?

sp.speaker: KATRINKA
sp.p: My brother Katrinket has disappeared - killed perhaps by Demidoff -

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: Kill Katrinket - me - why I couldn't kill a fly -

sp.speaker: KATRINKA
sp.p: So you are Demidoff - the high priest of black art. Advances to him, threatening. Where is my brother?

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: He's on vacation.

sp.speaker: KATRINKA
sp.p: Where?

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: I - he - he's vacated - that's all I know. Don't worry about him - he's all right. Looks at her affectionately. Ah, now I see why I loved him so. Takes KATRINKA's hand.

sp.speaker: KATRINKA
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: Because he is the tinfoil - counterfeit, I mean counter-part of your own beautiful self -

sp.speaker: KATRINKA
sp.p: Snatches her hand away, indignantly. How dare you -

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: I dare anything for your sake - Clasps her around waist. Your beauty has metamorphised me into an ardent lover whose passion-sapped intellectual faculties are overwhelmingly saturated with a boisterous, burning, bubbling desire to become yours and yours alone.

sp.speaker: KATRINKA
sp.p: You win - Then thou will join me.

lg.l: The college man is rollicking frollicking all the live long day
The summery, summery girl is full of joy,
The bachelor is practical, tactical in his genial way
No frautical, autical words does he employ
The widow laughs most merrily, cheerily bubbling o'er with mirth,
No fearfully tearfully words she interlards
But the frappery, snappery, muttery, sputtery people of this earth,
Are the member of the matrimonial guards.
The long lean husband and his roly poly better half.
The plain dressed man whose wife looks like a circus lithograph.
The female nagger,
The chronic jagger,
All are marching to the music of a cry or laugh.

div.stage: ENTER JELIKOFF followed by PESHOFKI - JELIKOFF rushes to DEMIDOFF for assistance.

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN
sp.p: You are not for him - I have swear it?

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN
sp.p: You are 'usband of 'er - 'er whom I love - Points to JELIKOFF.

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: I don't follow you.

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN
sp.p: I am slav - I am soldier - I stab, I kill. BUS: with sword.

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: That's quite possible - but what am I to infer from that?

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN
sp.p: I love 'er - Point to JELIKOFF wife of you, if you shall stand in my way I will make of you a dead body.

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: But my friend there are obstacles.

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN
sp.p: I care nothing for obstacles, I am slav, I am soldier, I stab, I kill.

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: But you don't seem to understand - this is no lady -

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN
sp.p: Ah, you insult her. She is a perfect lady - yes.

sp.speaker: JELIKOFF
sp.p: I tried to explain but -

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN
sp.p: Fair Lady you love not him eh? No - well you shall love me - as for him, he shall die.

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: Will you leave me then for a minute. To JELIKOFF You've got me into a nice mess haven't you?

sp.speaker: JELIKOFF
sp.p: It isn't my fault.

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: Well, you get out of it the best way you can - To CAPTAIN Sir - I interpose no opposition - go ahead.

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN
sp.p: Ah - so you shall live To JELIKOFF And you shall fly wis me, is it not?

sp.speaker: JELIKOFF
sp.p: In a deep voice, pushes him back. Stand back, are you bereft of your senses?

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN
sp.p: Ah, I am die of love

sp.speaker: JELIKOFF
sp.p:
See here, this has gone far enough -
Takes CAPTAIN by arm, takes him up stage, talks earnestly to him in pantomime for five or six seconds, they then both look round at JELIKOFF, who is standing LC unconscious. CAPTAIN starts back as if struck, places hand to forehead.

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN
sp.p: Ah - I am craze - I thought 'is voice was terribly hoarse for a lady.

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: Yes, that's a terrible horse on you - and I think if you'd stop smoking these... BUS: with cigarettes it would help some.

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN
sp.p: Ah, I cannot believe it -- it is a scheme of you to so separate us?

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: Pish! Maluska!

sp.speaker: JELIKOFF
sp.p:
Help. Organ and Chorus off stage.
ENTER GOGOL

sp.speaker: GOGOL
sp.p: It is over - they're married - ha - ha - BUS.

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: Aside The laugh is on the other foot BUS. Ha, ha - Imitates him. And now to congratulate my daughter. Father to Princess Alexandovitch - Husband to Princess Ruchkowski by the St. Nicholas. I shall be a Grand Duke before I know it ...

sp.speaker: GOGOL
sp.p: Fool your daughter is wedded to a pauper.

lg.l: Day of joy when young hearts are mated
Golden chains are linking soul to soul
Bride and groom, we pray you are fated
To be happy as the seasons roll.
While unrestricted bliss
To what we wish the pretty bride
Yes it is not amiss
If at this time we should confide
That we, quite young and fair,
Would single life forswear,
And join this happy pair.
Should you decide.
The lillies of your love may die,
The rose my lose its bloom
To-day we're happy you and I,
The morrow may bring gloom.
Maid of the meadow ope thine eyes
Life is a dream of paradise
No constant fears
Bring coutless tears
Love's choicest wine
Is over thine.
Maid of the sunshine ope thine eyes
Life is a sweet surprise
Would I were the meadow maid
No daughter ruled by mystics hand
Oh fates in all you might arrayed
Oh tell what you have planned.
Bride of the sunshine I'd be
Bride of the summer breeze
Bride of the blue-tinted sea
Bride of the murmuring trees.

sp.speaker: CHORUS
sp.p: Speech - speech -

sp.speaker: BORIS
sp.p: Friends - dear friends I -

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: Good!

sp.speaker: BORIS
sp.p: Friends - dear friends I -

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: Aside to BORIS Good, don't speak again. You're giving them a pain.

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN
sp.p: The grand Duke has arrive from the Moscow.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p: Oh shameless imposter this means your arrest.
sp.note: Transcriber's Note: Music No. 10d, "It is a well established fact" (or the Ammonia Song, is not found in the London script.
sp.stage: After song EXIT OMNES except DUKE - DUCHESS, CAPTAIN and Russian soldiers.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p: Signals curtain to be drawn. Captain!

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN
sp.p: Your Imperial Highness.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p: Inform the -
Princess Stephanie of Ruchkowski - that as soon as her fainting fit is over I wish to see her here.
The Princess Stephanie.
Ha ha!

sp.speaker: DUCHESS
sp.p: The imposter - what impertinence.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p: I little thought that when his Imperial Majesty the Czar conferred on you the title and estates of the late Princess Ruchkowski woman that we should find a spurious imitation here - in our own mountain retreat.

sp.speaker: DUCHESS
sp.p: I wonder who she is.

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: The Princess is really unable. Shouts and turns to L

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p: Well - I didn't send for you.

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: No - I - I'm an accident - I mean -
I'm very glad your Highness didn't send for me - I -
I can hear the dungeon yawning for me - I must face it out -

Your highness - it was all a joke - a harmless little joke - and Anna borrowed the title intending to put it back - immediately - in fact we have returned it - The real Princess has forgiven us - and -
all is as merry as ha - ha -
as a church bells -

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p: So the Princess has forgiven you. Turns to the Grand DUCHESS

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: Oh yes - Your Highness - and enters into the spirit of the joke with us - thought it was great fun - asked us to do it again - Oh the Princess is a cork - tres charmant - tres charmant - your Highness speaks French?
sp.stage: The Grand DUKE looks angrily at DEMIDOFF, who notices this and his spirits drop as he glances from the DUKE to the DUCHESS and sees they are frowning.
sp.p: It was Gogol's idea your Highness.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p: The Deputy Governor?

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: Yes - Your Highness - Oh, he ought to know better, I warned him - but -
Ah - at last - Your Highness.
You will explain to his Imperial Highness, the Grand Duke - but first permit me to introduce to you - Her Highness, the Princess Stephanie of Ruchkowski.
sp.stage: The DUCHESS rises indignantly, the DUKE signals her to remain quiet.
sp.p: Princess, this is his Highness the Grand Duke -

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p: And who are you, Sir?

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: Me? Why I'm - To KATRINKA Do you mind introducing me?

sp.speaker: KATRINKA
sp.p: No - no - I - BUS: DEMIDOFF

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p: So - this is the Princess eh -

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: The real thing - she will tell you it was with her consent we temporarily utilized the gognomen of Ruchkowski, eh, Princess?

sp.speaker: KATRINKA
sp.p: No - no - it is useless. Your Imperial Highness knows only too well that I -

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p: Ah - you acknowledge the fraud -

sp.speaker: KATRINKA
sp.p: Yes I -

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: No you don't - To DUKE Your Royal Highness it was this way.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p: Silence sir.

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: I was only going to say -

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p: Silence or - Motions to GUARDS, DEM: BUSINESS, makes signs intimating that it was her fault. How came you to assume?

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p:
She didn't assume - she is the real article. You see it was this way. My daughter Anna, the present Princess Alexandervitch, in a spirit of harmless levity accepted the title of Ruchkowski - with the permission of course, of the original hold of the stake, I mean the title - TO KATRINKA Eh, Princess? Then to DUKE Your Imperial Highness found it out - laughed merrily at the joke - forgave it - and all's well that ends well - eh?
Laughs heartily, looks around but no else laughs. The Grand DUKE does not respond to DEMIDOFF's flow of spirits and he gradually subsides.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p: To GUARD If that man interrupts again give him an inch of cold steel -

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p:
Aside This looks like a conspiracy to railroad me to the better land - OFFICER BUS: with sword. I was only soliloquizing!
ENTER ANNA and BORIS

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p: Ah, Boris -

sp.speaker: BORIS
sp.p: Your Highness Salutes him to the Princess. Your Highness' servant.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p: I'm sorry to see you mixed up in this affair Boris.

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: A man is so liable to be mixed up in his own wedding Your Highness - Laughs lightly - the DUKE glares at him.

sp.speaker: BORIS
sp.p: Your Highness - permit me to introduce my newly wedded bride -

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p: Ah, congratulations - BUS: bow to ANNA who returns salute. You have conformed to the Czar's will I presume?

sp.speaker: BORIS
sp.p: I have - my wife was until an hour ago the Princess Stephanie of Ruchkowski -

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: No - no - that's part of the joke - we don't want it dug up again - Takes his arm and leads him away from DUKE. For goodness sake don't - she has your name now - forget all about hers - let bygones be bygones -

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p: I didn't catch the name -

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: Aside Prepare to receive cavalry. Braces himself.

sp.speaker: BORIS
sp.p: Until recently the Princess Stephanie of Ruchkowski -

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p:
Indeed -
DUCHESS How dare they!

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p:
Aside Oh this is double darrel Hades -
ENTER CAPTAIN, bringing in JELIKOFF followed by GOGOL and SOPHIA.

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN
sp.p: Your I'ghness - I can find no Princess but - I suspect this lady is something of what she does not look -

sp.speaker: JELIKOFF
sp.p: I am innocent -

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p:
Perhaps you are the Princess Stephanie of Ruchkowski -
JELIKOFF looks at DEMIDOFF.

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: Discovered at last. I knew the real culprit could not escape your Imperial Highness' penetrating eye.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p: That makes three ladies -

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: Up his sleeve so to speak. Beats three jacks -

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p:
Who is the guilty one?
Pause

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: Aside What! Unanimous silence.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p: Come....speak....I'll give you two minutes to make up your minds which is the guilty one.

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: After due consideration I have hit upon this plan We'll deny the allegation Points to GOGOL Saying he's the guilty man.

lg.l: The opinion of your daughter
As the legal facts I scan
Is that we together ought to
Say Gogol's the guilty man.
While your plan commands attention
Though I cannot tell you why
Have you thought that we should mention
We can prove an alibi.
While I'll swear to anything you tell him
Still I have another plan
Sympathetic sobs from Ann would quell him
And indict that guilty man
So sob dear Anna
In a manner
To convict that man.

sp.speaker: ALL

lg.l: If we find the Duke won't listen
Then we'll try (Katrinka's/my little) plan
Tears in both (your/my) must glisten
Proving he's the guilty man.

sp.stage: DEMIDOFF, KATRINKA, ANNA and JELIKOFF BUS:

lg.l: After consultation most intense
With naught of malice or propense
Our meeting's indiviudal sense
Is he's the guilty one.
What I - were not your highness here
This fellow I would thrash
I'd put an end to his career
Of lying, with the lash
My nephew headless of all consequences
Took that female for his lawful wife.
This charlatan with subtle inferences
Worked the scheme, so they are bound for life.
How dare you speak of her who is a Princess
Someone hold me ere I strike him down
Your action Gogol without doubt convinces
Everybody that you are a blooming clown.

sp.speaker: DUKE

lg.l: Your conduct and your words are shady
The Princess is this noble lady
The real imported article at last.

sp.p: But why is he so sad and overcast. Pointing to BORIS

sp.speaker: BORIS
sp.p: Anna wife - be true -

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: Now Borry don't get angry and forsake her.

sp.speaker: BORIS
sp.p: Anna, who are you?

sp.speaker: ANNA
sp.p: The daughter of a travelling fakir.

lg.l: The daughter of a fakir
Oh see the horses gaily speeding
On over roads bedecked with snow
On now our steeds are bravely leading
Over hill and dale we madly go.
Stop though your ways are very dark
This time I've overreached the mark
You'll find this wedding is no lark
For I'm a beggar -

div.stage: BUS: hands edict to Grand DUKE.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p: Spoken through music. Imperial Decree - Prince Boris - should he marry anyone below the rank of Princess shall forfeit his title and estates to the nearest of kin by command of Nicholas, Czar of all the Russians.

lg.l: Ah forgive me I knew not the sadness
That my life should entail upon thine
Tho' my soul is bereft of all gladness
I love thee with a passion devine.
In my arms let me fold thee for ever
For my heart is ceaselessly thine
Hope foretells we shall never more sever
I love thee with a passion divine.
Boshezar is chrani
Ssill rigi dershan nui
Zarst win na Slawyi na
Sla wu nam
Zarst win na slack wragan
Za prawa sslawnyi
Boshe zar is chrani
Caballa Obdalla
Hawoka Sulon
Hawoka ... Sulon Chorus
Venus Goddess of love ope wide thy shell like ears
And by the memory of thy loves
The cooing of thy snowy doves
I, Demidoff the great mumbo, jumbo of the seers
Direct you
Expect you
By mystic signs and magic rite
To take her from their sight.

sp.speaker: CHORUS
sp.l: On wings of lightning she appears

lg.l: Love's the pleasure, love's the pain
Love's the sickle, love's the grain
Love's the sunshine, love's the rain
Love is everything.
Sad was the day when I came to this planet
Sadder the day when my daughter was born
The heart of the world is harder than granite
My poor suffering sould with anguish is torn.

sp.speaker: CHORUS
sp.p: Death and degradation to the cringing charlatan!

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: T0 KATRINKA You plainly see They don't like me I am a hated man

sp.speaker: CHORUS
sp.p: Death and degradation to the cringing charlatan!

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: 'Tis my belief My days are brief If they work out their plan.

lg.l: Thoughts of dungeons deep and clammy
Fills his soul with woe
Tho' he'll sorrow
On the morrow
To Siberia he'll go,

div.stage: BORIS and men draw swords rush on DEMIDOFF; when headed by CAPTAIN who push back BORIS and friends; DEMIDOFF tries to explain but is put under arrest. CAPTAIN reads warrant calling for PRINCESS STEPHANIE. BORIS points out KATRINKA, as the Princess, who is placed under arrest. JELIKOFF tries to escape but is arrested, DEMIDOFF, JELIKOFF, and KATRINKA hand-cuffed together and marched off with troops as:

div.head:
The Charlatan:
Act III
div.stage: SCENE: The exterior of the Palace of the Grand Duke.
DISCOVERED: At rise of curtain, RUSSIAN SOLDIERS and COSSACKS, ANNA dressed as in Act 1.

sp.speaker: CHORUS
sp.p: Why, who's this?

sp.speaker: ANNA
sp.p: LC, Aside. If I can only find the Grand Duke and tell him all, surely he will restore Boris - his title and estates - the Grand Duke -
sp.note: Transcriber's Note: Music No. 13 - Anna's solo "Oh, Sunlit Sea beyond the West" and the Reprise of "Seventh Son" was not found in the London production script.
sp.p: I want to see the Grand Duke -

sp.speaker: CHORUS
sp.p: The Grand Duke - she wants to see the Grand Duke, ha, ha - Laughs and points at her.

sp.speaker: ANNA
sp.p: I've important business with him.

sp.speaker: CHORUS
sp.p: She has important business with the Grand Duke, ha, ha - Points at her. Ha - ha -

sp.speaker: ANNA
sp.p: Angrily - stamping her foot. Do you call yourselves men?

sp.speaker: CHORUS
sp.p: Do we call ourselves men - ha - ha -

sp.speaker: A SOLDIER
sp.p: I'm a man and I'll prove it by kissing you.

div.stage: Siezes hold of ANNA - the rest form a circle and dance around them - ANNA struggles - boxes SOLDIER's ears. OMNES dance around and laugh.

sp.speaker: CHORUS MAN
sp.p: The Captain.

sp.speaker: OMNES
sp.p: The Captain!!!

div.stage: OMNES disperse rapidly and stand in military order as when curtain went up - ANNA rushes off L.I. and slams door.
ENTER CAPTAIN. OMNES salute - COSSAUKS BUS: with spears.

Murmurs louder - drums beat off stage - yells of mob or cries of "Down with the Charlatan etc." ANNA rushes off stage R as ENTER SOLDIERS with CARAVAN Cabinet which they place R.C. Soldiers keep mob back and finally push them out of gate. JELIKOFF and KATRINKA seat themselves R. They are handcuffed together.

SOLDIERS after closing gates C. stand up stage in twos and threes - then gradually disperse and EXIT C.D. One of the soldiers opens curtains of cabinet disclosing DEMIDOFF tied to cabinet - completely loaded with chains. Soldiers must be seen through gate C.

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: I want some air.
sp.stage: Takes a long breath as if relieved.
sp.p: This may be exciting but I'm sure it's not healthy -
Will you please tell the General of the Commissariat Department I want something to eat....I'm starving.
I shall report you for incivility.

div.stage: Sees JELIKOFF and KATRINKA at table.

sp.speaker: JELLIKOFF
sp.p: - Katrinka - can't you get me a bite...I've already eaten part of this rope because it looked like sausage...

sp.speaker: JELIKOFF
sp.p: We have one or two troubles of our own.

sp.speaker: KATRINKA
sp.p: Not a wink of sleep all night ... He insisted on walking up and down the cell and of course I had to walk with him.

sp.speaker: JELIKOFF
sp.p: Does our trial take place to-day?

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: Don't you think we've been tried enough - all I ask is to be found guilty and put out of my misery - If only Anna were here.

div.stage: ENTER CAPTAIN, a soldier with a tray before him. CAPTAIN points over to L. where JELIKOFF is sitting then throw him a kiss and soldier places tray before him.)

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN
sp.p: To Soldier Release them.. To JELIKOFF When he shall be dead... Points to DEMIDOFF there shall be no more obstacle....eh?

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p:
Still up stage in caravan. I wonder if he's talking about me?
Soldier unfastens KATRINKA and JELIKOFF then EXIT.

sp.speaker: JELIKOFF
sp.p: Preparing to sit down and enjoy meal. Oh this is something like.

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: Anxiously. What about me...don't I eat?

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN
sp.p: Silence...

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p:
I'm bigger than he is ... I need more food - As CAPTAIN laughs and EXITs R.
I'm turning into a vacuum I ... Sees JELIKOFF making preparations to eat. Thanks, I don't mind if I do - Pause Jelikoff I trust you are a gentleman.
KATRINKA stands looking on as if she would like to be invited. JELIKOFF goes on eating, takes no notice of others.
Jelikoff...In polite circles it is not considered good form to eat without asking those present to join you. Groans, Pause. Say will you stop smacking your lips ... I said it was not good form. Sees that JELIKOFF does not notice him. Say, give us a bite, will you?

sp.speaker: JELIKOFF
sp.p: To Katrinka. Is he talking to me?

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: Katrinka! KATRINKA goes to him. Are we watched?

sp.speaker: KATRINKA
sp.p: Looks around. Only the sentry.

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: Well, I'm going to make a break for the balance of that breakfast. Here's where I put prestidigitating to a practical purpose! BUS: of pretending to wriggle out of ropes as trick. R. at table - as he divides breakfast with KATRINKA. Do you know it's one of the marvels of the present century what great big hogs little men can make of themselves.

sp.speaker: KATRINKA
sp.p: Perhaps we've tied him too tightly, he may be choking.

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: Calls out. Jelikoff stop choking - Trumpet

sp.speaker: KATRINKA
sp.p: The Grand Duke is arriving.

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: Let him arrive...We demand justice - Gogol has deceived me, his daughter Sophia has deceived you - and they have both deceived Jelikoff. The story of our wrongs is a perfect chain of sequential circumstances ... that reminds me we must let Jelikoff out to give evidence. They go up stage, open curtains disclosing Jelikoff. As they untie him. You are the most troublesome individual who ever got entangled up in my horoscope....

sp.speaker: JELIKOFF
sp.p: Sir, if I ever get out of this place alive - I shall decline further association with you.

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: R Ingrate...you were starving when I found you.

sp.speaker: JELIKOFF
sp.p: C I am starving now.

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p:
But look at the meals you've had in the interim.
ENTER SOLDIERS headed by CAPT.P: they range themselves on steps of Palace. ENTER GRAND DUKE and DUCHESS, followed by BORIS, GOGOL, and SOPHIA.
Chairs are placed for GRAND DUKE RC. 2 soldiers guard Cabinet, four more arrange themselves by DEMIDOFF and KATRINKA under directions from CAPTAIN
NOTE: - As soon as DEMIDOFF hears and sees Soldiers ENTERING he goes back to cabinet and pretends to be struggling up to it. He is released during musical scene; as soon as he is released, which will be about end of musical number, he appeasls to DUKE.
MUSIC effect with chains - a sort of general denunciation of DEMIDOFF's crimes.
Your Imperial Highness I demand justice - I have been cruelly wronged -

sp.speaker: GOGOL
sp.p: Laughs Wronged...You..

sp.speaker: BORIS
sp.p: Triple assassin -

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: Why triple..isn't plain, simple assassin bad enough? Ah Borry my boy these are harsh words to use to father.

sp.speaker: BORIS
sp.p: Where is my wife?

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p: How should I know?

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: You've had me trussed up in that cabinet like a toasted squab...she's probably off on her honeymoon alone - you know how independent women are in these days.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p:
I will find a means to make you tell the truth. Signals to CAPTAIN who motions off stage R.
ENTER TWO BIG villanious looking MEN dressed like executioners, they carry various weapons of torture including thumbscrews - spiked collar - pincers, etc, etc.

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: Frightened Here - I'll tell the truth - without means - I'll - Points to spiked collar. What's that? Ah - now I know what Peshofki meant when he said I was going to get it in the neck. Takes pincers, BUS: Rather than wear that, I prefer to be pinched.

sp.speaker: BORIS
sp.p: Those tortures are trifling compared to what will follow -

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p: Merely a preliminary proceeding.

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: Are there going to be any supplementary proceedings?

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p: Enough...what is your answer...to these charges of witchcraft and assassination.

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p:
Da... Beckons to JELIKOFF who comes trembling to his side, then to KATRINKA who also comes to him - they converse together - the others are not supposed to hear.
The GRAND DUKE, BORIS and GOGOL confer up stage.
Aside to JELIKOFF and KATRINKA. We've got one chance in a million - the most infinitesimal flaw in any link of our chain of evidence will irretrievably ruin us.

sp.speaker: KATRINKA
sp.p: L I'll stick by you old boy.

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: You're all right but I'm afraid of this fellow... To JELIKOFF Can you remember anything?

sp.speaker: JELIKOFF
sp.p: R Everything but...who did it?

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: Who did it...Gogol...you two inch plank.

sp.speaker: JELIKOFF
sp.p: What did he do?

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: What did who do?

sp.speaker: JELIKOFF
sp.p: Gogol?...

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: Us...you hickory pated idiot...He did all that we are supposed to have done -

sp.speaker: JELIKOFF
sp.p: Did he...I thought we did?

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: Go on - plead guilty - get it in the neck - get pinched. Shakes head. The old oaken bucket is a temple of profound thought compared to that... Raps JELIKOFF on head. sarcophagus of sawdust.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p:
Rapping septre on chair. Come...what answer do you make to these charges?
Pause - DEMIDOFF, KATRINKA, and JELIKOFF look at each other.

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: Now then all together... After an effort - beats time. "May it please your Imperial Highness" Trip with BUSINESS.

sp.speaker: GOGOL
sp.p: It's a conspiracy...a collusion.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p:
Separate the prisoners.
BUSINESS of soldiers
Looking over paper. Demidoff...you are required by this tribunal of justice to produce...the Princess Alexandovitch - your daughter Anna -

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: All right I'll go and look for her - BUSINESS the guards stop him.

sp.speaker: BORIS
sp.p: He has spirited her away.

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: You're a - if my hands weren't tied I --

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p: Silence -

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: No I am tongue tied --

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p: You are accused of spiriting away an old fortune telling sorceress.

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: That was my daughter Anna -

sp.speaker: BORIS
sp.p: Your daughter?

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p: Enough - you will answer for these two lives with your head - now for the others --

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: Oh! there are others, eh?...What a pity I haven't any more heads.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p: What have you done with Jelikoff the tragedian?

sp.speaker: GOGOL
sp.p: Aside to JELIKOFF up stage. If you wish to save your own life remain silent.

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: jelikoff...oh, that's easy... To Jelikoff

p.stage: JELIKOFF up stage looks up, pretending he does no know DEMIDOFF.

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: Jelikoff... Louder Jelikoff...supeak up

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p: It is useless - the man has disappeared...

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: No, he hasn't - there he is. Points to JELIKOFF Speak, you are Jelikoff the comedian?

sp.speaker: JELIKOFF
sp.p: Tragedian!

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: What's the difference...you're Jelikoff...come speak up.

sp.speaker: JELIKOFF
sp.p: Yes I ... that is ... I think I better not. Looks helplessly at GOGOL then at DEMIDOFF.

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN
sp.p: ...'E is 'usband of 'er...she would die for 'im.

sp.speaker: JELIKOFF
sp.p: No -yes.

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p:
Looks around helplessly. I'm through.
Takes collar from executioner, puts it on, finds it hurts - hands it back.

sp.speaker: GOGOL
sp.p: Aside to KATRINKA Contradict Demidoff.

sp.speaker: KATRINKA
sp.p: Never - I said I would stand by him and I will.

sp.speaker: GOGOL
sp.p: Aside But if you deny his story...they will think he is insane and his life will be saved.

sp.speaker: KATRINKA
sp.p: True!

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p: Reading Paper. There is one more count in this indictment

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: Laughing bitterly. Count...why not make it a Prince or a Grand Duke...

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p: The boy - known as Katrinkat has disappeared, where is he?

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: Laughs satirically. Oh, this is simply wasting my time...these proceedings are degenerating into a species of entertainment known as hippodroming and my breath is too valuable to waste. To KATRINKA Just tell them Katrinket -

sp.speaker: GOGOL
sp.p: Aside to Katrinka Remember!

sp.speaker: KATRINKA
sp.p: Shakes head - to OMNES. His mind must be wandering.

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p:
Looking around helplessly. I guess it is - my head will be wandering around with it soon. Sees GOGOL. Gogol...it may sound like sarcasm but...I appeal to your sense of honour...
GOGOL waves him away.
Did you not lead me into this hapless mass of chaotic complication, did you not make me the quadruplex assassin - I appear to be?

sp.speaker: GOGOL
sp.p: I?

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p:
Aye -
GOGOL laughs sardonically.
Jelikoff! Appealing JELIKOFF looks up and shakes head sadly as if sorry. Katrinket! KATRINKA looks at him, shakes her head sadly. Boris! BORIS waves him away. Looks around> Elected by an overwhelming majority... As he takes instruments of torture from executioners. To the victor belongs the spoils.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p: Enough! To KATRINKA AND JELIKOFF. You two are free - They are hustled out by soldiers. As for yor Demidoff, you may prepare to meet your fate.

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: What kind fate?

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN
sp.p: Looks around. You would escape is it?

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: Is it what?

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN
sp.p: If you shall make a separation wis Madam Demidoff - you shall go - escape.

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: Separation -- I'll make an assignment - deed of gift or Power of Attorney - anything.

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN
sp.p: And you will leave Bohkaria.

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: Leave it ... I'll tear the entire map of Russia out of my Atlas and make you a present of it.

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN
sp.p: Points to D.L. Take a door there - opposite the wall - Points L It leads to an alley - you see.

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: No - I don't.

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN
sp.p: It leads to an alley --

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: It must be a blind alley I don't see...

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN
sp.p: Points to D.L.I There -- that door...

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: Oh!

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN
sp.p: Wait there...you climb a tree - I will bring a uniform...

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: And I shall be up a tree? Eh? Yes...I guess...I shall!

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN
sp.p:
Go...I will watch...
Strolls up stage, talks to Sentries - obviously attracts their attention to something up stage.

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p:
Going quietly towards DL. Let me see...I must climb a blind alley till I come to a tree and then... Looks off. that form crouching in the doorway - It's Anna...Anna, 'tis I ...Demidoff...your poor perturbed parent...
ENTER ANNA
I'm so glad I... Hysterically I...ha...ha...I've found you...I've found you... Then angrily Where have you been?...How dare you lead me such a dance? ANNA steps back. No - don't go...don't go.

sp.speaker: ANNA
sp.p: I came to confess all to the Grand Duke - I was afraid of the soldiers and hid over there...

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: Afraid...How can your father's daughter utter such a word...afraid of a paltry regiment of soldiers - I've been dancing on loaded dynamite all day and hain't flinched a muscle - but I'll show them...hush, go in there... BUS: points to cabinet, goes up, stands at L of cabinet so taht CAPTAIN and 2 Sentries cannot see him - ANNA EXITS into cabinet. CAPTAIN P: looks around, does not see DEMIDOFF.

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN
sp.p: He have gone. To Soldiers The prisoner have escape, sound alarm... One of the soldiers beats a drum - pause. You will find him up one tree in a - alley. ENTER OMNES hurriedly. Shoot him...shoot him.. To OMNES Demidoff have escape ... To Soldier Shoot him - shoot him dead.

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: Sauntering round cabinet so that OMNES can see him. Yes...be very careful on that point - I don't want to be killed on the instalment plan.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p: Captain, what's the meaning of this?

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p:
It means your Royal Highness that although the alley may be blind, I am not...the Captain... Points to Captain. wanted me to escape so that he might make me a storage warehouse for bullets - but virtue is ever triumphant - and justice invariably poetic - as I propose to make... Pointing to GOGOL that arch-villian eat the indigestible fate he has prepared for me.
Noise off stage at gate...ENTER JELIKOFF and KATRINKET dressed in their original first Act costumes - they struggle with the soldiers and burst forward. CHORUS ENTER

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p: What is it?

sp.speaker: JELIKOFF
sp.p: My Lord...My Lord...an injustice most foul -

sp.speaker: KATRINKA
sp.p: Points to DEMIDOFF. He has committed no crime.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p: Silence...who are they?

sp.speaker: BORIS
sp.p: The young page Katrinket and the tragedian Jelikoff - oh! if only SHE came back....

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: The cat came back..why not she?...Your royal highness...I charge Rasselloff Gogol with attempting to defraud his nephew Boris of his title and estates -

sp.speaker: GOGOL
sp.p: How will you prove it?

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p:
Anna herself shall testify...I suppose you all thought I spirited her away in earnest - ha - ha - an excellent compliment to my professional handiwork. Behold!
Part of Incantation No. during which the scenes appear in cabinet and are dimmed from view after which ANNA appears in the same costume as she first appeared in Act 1. After have them with tenor and soprano passages at end of which BORIS rushes to embrace her - she holds him out at arm's length.

sp.speaker: ANNA
sp.p: No - No...I am an imposter.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p: At whose instigation did you assume at title?

sp.speaker: ANNA
sp.p:
Points to GOGOL. His!
GOGOL goes to EXIT.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p: I shall investigate and if true will petition the Czar to restore you your title and estates...

sp.speaker: GOGOL
sp.p:
Boris...
BORIS waves him away.

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: Son-in-law- she is yours - with or without your title. Katrinket...kiss your daughter, the Princess Alexandrovitch.

sp.speaker: KATRINKA
sp.p: My daughter?

sp.speaker: DEMIDOFF
sp.p: Well, she will be when--- Kisses KATRINKA's hand, puts KATRINKA's hand through his arm.

sp.speaker: JELIKOFF
sp.p: To CAPTAIN in a deep voice. Well - what is it?

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN
sp.p: Good'eaven...'e is not wife of 'im - no...good 'eaven.
